posts.name:
Mark R. Koesterer
Mark R. Koesterer
posts.content:
Day 22 of The Rocky Steps Challenge: Unlocking Influence 

Why Young Athletes Need a Plan for NIL Content Posting

How do you get started building your brand and creating content for NIL (Name, Image, and Likeness) opportunities?

In today‚Äôs lesson, I‚Äôm answering one of the most common questions I hear from athletes and creatives:‚ÄúWhere do I begin?‚Äù

To help, I‚Äôve created a list of 20 content ideas specifically designed for young athletes. These ideas will guide you in showcasing your skills, personality, and values while building an authentic brand that attracts opportunities.

Here‚Äôs why a plan is essential for NIL content:
* It ensures consistency and professionalism.
* It helps attract sponsors by highlighting what makes you unique.
* It gives you the tools to stay organized and compliant with NIL guidelines.

Every day, I share insights from my journey and the lessons I‚Äôve learned about creating content, building influence, and supporting others in doing the same.

Let‚Äôs connect: Are you a young athlete, coach, or creative looking to unlock your influence? Drop your favorite content idea or NIL question in the comments‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to hear from you!


You can listen to my thoughts HERE:
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! A solid content plan is key for young athletes to shine in the NIL landscape. Excited to see the ideas you share! üåü

posts.name:
Dan Goodman
Dan Goodman
posts.content:
If managers were accountable for placing employees on PIPs, there would be a lot less PIPs. 

It should be a reflection on both the manager and employee, not just the employee.

Not a weapon for a manager to manage an employee out of the business that they don't like or want around anymore.

Accountability must go in both directions.

comments.commentText: Well said Dan. In some other countries, there are no such things as PIPs but domestic enquiries chaired & attended by committee members all of whom has not worked with the employee concerned. The employee's manager is not to be involved whatsoever. That's to ensure fairness & no conflict of interests. Whereas PIP ( from what I have read & heard) is written by the manager concerned & also assessed & concluded by himself!! That can't be fair..In other countries, if the employee is unjustly dismissed, he /she can be compensated usually with 24 months back pay plus reinstatement. Further the employment lawyer there who acts for employees only is not allowed ( at least morally or professionally ) to act for the Employer even in other unrelated cases or different Employers. That compelled everyone to be fair & honest.

Seng Lee Jot i‚Äôve consulted with more than a dozen people from other countries, including in Europe, Asia, and north and South America. The United States has some of the worst protections for employees of most countries that I‚Äôve worked with people in.
Agree I always held my managers accountable for turnover. Either they had no eye for talent and hired poorly or couldn‚Äôt develop talent who was failing under their wing.

Dan Goodman it starts with the leadership team developing a solid business plan for success and each persons defined role. The sales manager is then championed with setting the proper expectations, training their team, delivering the implementation of the plan and understanding that their success is a culmination of the team success and that is their responsibility to deliver.

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Accountability should be a two-way street, fostering growth and collaboration rather than becoming a tool for exclusion.

posts.name:
Daisy Auger-Dom√≠nguez (she/her/ella)
Daisy Auger-Dom√≠nguez (she/her/ella)
posts.content:
I‚Äôve spent the past few days on calls and emails, helping leaders, HR professionals, and DEI practitioners figure out how to meet this moment without burning out.  It‚Äôs not uncharted territory‚Äîwe‚Äôve weathered years of upheaval, learning to adapt, keep things moving, and care for our teams. But it‚Äôs still hard, and it helps to remember that you don‚Äôt have to do it alone.

Navigating this moment can feel like walking a tightrope. The issues demanding our attention seem endless. On the one hand, we‚Äôre expected to stay neutral, steering clear of politics at work, and on the other, staying silent when team members feel the real impacts of decisions can feel like letting them down.

In moments like these, lean on the beautiful basics:

 Be a steady presence. You don‚Äôt need to have all the answers‚Äîno one does right now. What matters most is showing up for your team with care and consistency. Build trust and show them you‚Äôll figure out whatever comes next together.

 Lean into your workplace rhythms. Every team member should know that a safe work environment is a priority‚Äîa place where they can turn, be heard, and find support‚Äîwhile respecting that some may choose to opt-out. If statements are your thing, go for it. It doesn‚Äôt have to be a big production. Use meetings, check-ins, or 1:1s as intentional moments to listen and connect. A simple "How can I support you?" or a thoughtful note can go a long way.

 Be clear about safety and well-being. Let your team know it‚Äôs OK (and encouraged) to step away, recharge, and care for themselves or their families. Be equally clear that harm to co-workers won‚Äôt be tolerated. Revisit your shared values and code of conduct (or create one if missing). If formal benefits aren‚Äôt available, small gestures‚Äîlike gift cards, mindfulness breaks, or a fun playlist‚Äîcan boost energy and lift spirits for those feeling worried, disengaged or burned out.

 Don‚Äôt forget about you. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt pour from an empty cup‚Äù is a saying for a reason. Set boundaries, ask for support, and prioritize your well-being. You‚Äôre modeling what care and balance look like for your team.

If your organization‚Äôs values and principles feel unclear, let this be your signal to take stock.

Your team is paying attention. Show up with confidence, heart, and a steady presence. You‚Äôre not just navigating a moment; you‚Äôre shaping the conditions for your team to thrive. That‚Äôs powerful, meaningful work‚Äîand it starts with you.

How are you showing up for your teams right now?

comments.commentText: Thank you for this message Daisy Auger-Dom√≠nguez (she/her/ella). We are all working hard to navigate right now and messages like these are so important. Our team instituted weekly Open Forums to provide safe spaces to staff - these have been an important tool for us throughout the past few months.

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely love this! üôå Prioritizing care and connection is key to empowering our teams. Together, we can navigate these challenges!

posts.name:
Sudarshana Sinha
Sudarshana Sinha
posts.content:
"Wow, I knew it would work, but seeing the results still blew my mind!"- One of my clients said recently after putting my advice into action for her business.

Honestly, the recommendation seemed like a no-brainer to me‚ÄîI've spent years helping solopreneurs grow their businesses, so I know exactly what works. But seeing it all click for my client? That never gets old.

I spend a lot of time thinking about challenges like this, and the solutions I offer are ones I know will make a difference. What might seem basic to me can often be a game-changer for someone else who's still figuring things out.

And I bet you have some of those insights in your work too. What seems like second nature to you could be exactly what someone else needs to move their business forward.

My advice: Don‚Äôt hold back! Speak up and share your expertise. You never know when something you think is ‚Äúsimple‚Äù could be the breakthrough someone else needs.

What‚Äôs the best "basic" piece of advice you've shared that truly made an impact?

comments.commentText: That's so right! Sometimes, the simplest of advices can do wonders, it's so important to speak to someone about the challenges we face .

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Sometimes the simplest insights can spark the biggest changes. Cheers to sharing knowledge and uplifting each other!

posts.name:
Colby Wegter
Colby Wegter
posts.content:
How you‚Äôll prepare your people to scale without you.

You won‚Äôt leave them behind.

You hit a good run. You see a honeyhole of leads and sales.

But you‚Äôre already worried about your reputation suffering.

Because your employees aren‚Äôt ready to handle it.

They‚Äôll fail you.

Fire fighting. Sleepless nights.

You could look to hire.

‚Üí More overhead
‚Üí More work
‚Üí No guarantees

You could pass the opportunity

‚Üí No growth
‚Üí Less stress
‚Üí Potential unreached
‚Üí Mediocrity and stuck in neutral

No man‚Äôs land sucks. You need to grow.

And you need people to be ready.

Here‚Äôs how you‚Äôll do it:

Appoint a leader
Execution plan for the leader
Employee roadmaps for everyone else
Loom SOPs

Incredibly easy to understand.

Extremely difficult to execute.

But possible.

If you want to see how I did it when we were scaling the agency from $50K to $200K months, check this:

comments.commentText: Love the focus on people. A strong team makes scaling way less scary.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Investing in leadership and clear roadmaps is key to sustainable growth. Excited to learn more about your success story! üöÄ
